info.game_comments:
2001 International Championship final game 2.
From the Las Vegas Hilton.

(1, 1).clue: This "War and Peace" author's play "The Power of Darkness" was once banned in his native Russia

(2, 1).clue: He's the pop star who has thrilled fans with such albums as "Bad" & "Thriller"

(3, 1).clue: Also a classic Volkswagen, it's the insect with the greatest number of species

(4, 1).clue: In 1959 this spiritual leader of Tibet fled to exile in India

(5, 1).clue: The name of this Japanese electronics company comes from the Latin word for "sound"

(6, 1).clue: In Greek an arithmos is one of these, whether it's even, odd, rational, etc.

(1, 2).clue: Conor McPherson's haunting play "The Weir" is set in a pub in this country

(2, 2).clue: This action star seen here once held the title of "Best Built Man of Europe"

(3, 2).clue: Due to where mosquitos lay eggs, the "mosquito" species of this creature feeds on their larvae

(4, 2).clue: In 1953 a truce suspending the war in this divided country was signed at Panmunjom

(5, 2).clue: Seen here is the American Sign Language & what could be the international symbol for this restaurant chain

(6, 2).clue: Agape is Greek for the "brotherly" type of this

(1, 3).clue: Israeli playwright Nathan Alterman called his first play "Kineret, Kineret...", Kineret being Hebrew for the Sea of this

(2, 3).clue: Supermodels Heidi Klum & Claudia Schiffer were both born in this country

(3, 3).clue: The American F/A-18 fighter plane, or a paper-making wasp

(4, 3).clue: After a 43-year reign, King Gustavus V of this country died at the age of 92

(5, 3).clue: In 2000 Lukoil, Russia's largest oil company, bid on the gas stations that were part of this man's oil empire

(6, 3).clue: Arvi is this young animal seen here, often served souvlak

(1, 4).clue: The "Chushingura", about a band of avenging Ronin, is one of the most famous plays in this form of Japanese drama

(2, 4).clue: Chryssomallis is the last name of this Greek-born New Age pianist who goes by his first name

(3, 4).clue: Shakira sings of "Moscas en la Casa", these in the house

(4, 4).clue: The Warsaw Pact was created in 1955 to oppose this defense organization formed by the U.S. & European allies

(5, 4).clue: This brokerage house uses the logo seen here

(6, 4).clue: Astro means this, & examples include Procyon & Arcturus

(1, 5).clue: Juliette Binoche starred in the 2000 Broadway revival of this British playwright's 1978 classic "Betrayal"

(2, 5).clue: His film "La Vita e Bella" or "Life is Beautiful" was inspired by his father who was imprisoned in Bergen-Belsen

(3, 5).clue: The cells bees make for workers, males & queens are different in size, but all are this shape

(4, 5).clue: In 1952 Eritrea became part of this African country

(5, 5).clue: The Boulevard des Invalides is home to this French pharmaceuticals company, the maker of RU-486

(6, 5).clue: It's Greek for "market"; in English the "phobia" of it is the fear of public places

(1, 1).clue: Julius' palace chapel may have included a shrine to this love goddess that his family regarded as an ancestor

(2, 1).clue: In the 1960s & 1970s he won the world's heavyweight boxing title 3 times

(3, 1).clue: Known as Hoba & weighing 60 tons, the largest single known one of these was discovered in Africa in 1920

(4, 1).clue: His Florentine Pieta, intended for his own tomb, is a self-portrait of the sculptor holding the body of Christ

(5, 1).clue: If Arthur Miller had written "Before the Fall", it would be set in this garden

(6, 1).clue: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle used to imbibe at the London pub now named for this fictional detective

(1, 2).clue: In the palace swimming pool Julius might have practiced crossing this river & declaring "The die is cast"

(2, 2).clue: This German tennis star was ranked the world's No. 1 woman's player a record 186 straight weeks from 1987 to 1991

(3, 2).clue: Whether absolute or apparent, it's the measure of a star's brightness

(4, 2).clue: In 1928 this cubist & Julio Gonzalez pioneered the welded sculpture

(5, 2).clue: Aztec warriors who died in battle served the sun for 4 years, then were reborn as this tiny bird

(6, 2).clue: Spain's National Organization for the Blind maintains the touchy-feely Museo Tiflologico in this city

(1, 3).clue: In Caesar's map room you might find his plans to fight the Helvetii, a people from a region today known as this

(2, 3).clue: This Australian swimmer nicknamed "The Thorpedo" won the gold in the 400-meter freestyle at Sydney

(3, 3).clue: The star cluster known as the Pleiades or the Seven Sisters is found in this bullish constellation

(4, 3).clue: His male nude sculpture "The Age of Bronze" was titled "The Vanquished" when first exhibited in 1877

(5, 3).clue: In this, the top level of Islam's levels of heaven, you'll find the Most High

(6, 3).clue: When in Austria, try to visit the Hofburg Palace Chapel for a performance by this youthful group heard here

(1, 4).clue: 1 of the 2 other members of the First Triumvirate who might join Julius in the palace study

(2, 4).clue: In 1980, at age 23, this Spaniard became the first European to win the U.S. Masters golf tournament

(3, 4).clue: To honor the Beatles, 4 of these mini-planets were named McCartney, Lennon, Harrison & Starr

(4, 4).clue: This "hole-y" British sculptor created the "Draped Reclining Figure" for London's Time-Life Building

(5, 4).clue: Xena's son & Hercules' family are dead & residing in this wonderful afterlife area

(6, 4).clue: Jesus Christ lizards & poison arrow frogs inhabit the Serpentarium in this capital of Costa Rica

(1, 5).clue: In Julius Caesar's private chamber you might find this woman, the last of his 3 Roman wives

(3, 5).clue: This unit equal to 3.262 light years can be used to measure the distance between stars

(4, 5).clue: His bronze David from the 1430s was the first nude statue of the Renaissance

(5, 5).clue: The land of heroes to King Arthur, it was the Island of the Blessed in Celtic myth

(6, 5).clue: Often made from yams, fufu are yummy dumplings served in Accra, the capital of this African country

(0, 0).clue: Written in 1904, "Himno Istmeno" is the national anthem of this country that won its independence a year earlier
